items.q: Which infamous 1932 horror film featuring real carnival sideshow performers was banned in the UK for decades?
items.explanation: Tod Browning's film shocked contemporary audiences and severely damaged his career.

items.q: The iconic 'Sgt. Pepper' album cover features the Beatles holding brass instruments.
items.explanation: They pose in colorful marching band uniforms holding various brass and woodwind instruments.

items.q: Walt Disney personally won more Academy Awards than any other individual in history.
items.explanation: Disney won 22 competitive Oscars and several honorary ones.

items.q: What is the common cinematic term used to describe a story structure that begins in the middle of the action?
items.explanation: It drops the audience directly into the plot without prior exposition.

items.q: Who directed the deeply unsettling 1977 horror film 'Eraserhead'?
items.explanation: The low-budget surrealist film established his signature bizarre style.

items.q: What experimental 1967 Velvet Underground album, featuring Nico, sold poorly initially but influenced countless punk bands?
items.explanation: It famously features the Andy Warhol banana print on the cover.

items.q: In theatrical stage directions, what does 'downstage' mean?
items.a: The area of the stage closest to the audience.
items.explanation: The term comes from historical stages that were physically raked downward toward the crowd.

items.q: Which massive 1982 album by Michael Jackson remains the best-selling album of all time?
items.explanation: It produced seven top-ten singles and revolutionized music videos.

items.q: What pioneering 1993 game heavily popularized the first-person shooter genre on PC?
items.explanation: Developed by id Software, it set the standard for 3D action games.

items.q: Which influential playwright wrote 'Death of a Salesman' and 'The Crucible'?
items.explanation: His plays rigorously critiqued the American Dream and political hysteria.
